ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a lot of knowledge in Chinese vocabulary and grammar structures. My speaking skills increased a lot, along with my reading and writing.
Reading, Listening, Writing and Speaking Chinese
Improved Chinese vocabulary and learned several new sentence structures.

After the first year of Chinese (or prior experience with Chinese), where we acquired a ton of different basic grammatical structures, this semester was more about acquiring specific expressions and expanding our vocabulary while reviewing some past material. Speaking is generally the hardest language skill to acquire, and I feel like at the end of this semester, I have a much greater ability to come up with correctly formed sentences in conversation that express what I want to.
How to speak Chinese more fluently

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
I think that the tests should be in person, at least the oral and listening portions. I really did not enjoy the technological glitches with Lingco and having to deal with scheduling when to take the listening and oral portions. I guess oral is fine online, but I really think the listening portion should be in person. 
I think the strengths are the speaking practice during class. The weakness is the use of Quia homework and online Lingco tests. the Quiz homework was unclear how it was graded, and I didn't really know if what I was doing was counting. I also felt like the Quia was unnecessarily difficult and probably lowered my grade inaccurately.
The strengths are that it is very interactive. I wish there were more character writing exercises.
Lot of work, but you learn Chinese.

Strength: Daily engagement
Weakness: Lots of memorization

This course is full of strengths. The pacing is fast but manageable, the tests are very fair, and in general I would say the workload and stress level was decreased compared to the first year of Chinese at Yale. The textbook isn't the most aesthetically pleasing book in the world -- it's very bare -- and it's a bit outdated (for example, we had a chapter with some vocabulary about making long-distance phonecalls by calling the operator and requesting a particular extension, etc.), but it strikes a great balance between reviewing already acquired vocabulary and giving new vocabulary. A big strength to the textbook and the course is the range of useful expressions that we now know how to say; it's really rounding out our ability to say any sentence we can think of. The textbook in some ways is a weakness to the course because it doesn't have the sort of clarity on grammar that textbooks like Integrated Chinese do, and it also doesn't really explain the usage of important vocabulary items -- I feel like without my professor's guidance, I wouldn't have gotten a good sense of the meaning of certain words and how to use them grammatically.

Strengths: very understanding professor and very hill class environment. sometimes we dont learn from the book so thats refreshing. 
Weakness: homework everyday

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend it if you want to learn Chinese in an intensive environment and are ready for a pretty high workload. The class itself is relaxed and pretty easygoing, and there are a lot of completion assignments. However, the tests were pretty hard, and the homework was at times very challenging. So, while it is fun to learn Chinese, just be prepared that it is not easy.
Yes, if you want to learn Chinese, I highly recommend this sequence.
Yes, if you want to improve your vocabulary.

This class is a great next step to learning Chinese. My skills have improved so much! Chinese is a really amazing program at Yale. It's extremely structured and well-planned; every second is spent on something useful.
Yes, its a very organized department and you will be guaranteed to learn a lot of Chinese.
